image.altText: A gold medal on a blue ribbon rests on a velvet cushion

items.synopsis: An NT auditor-general's report found the agency used taxpayer dollars to pay the consultant, who was hired to prepare nominations for the agency's current and previous board members.

title.children: Use of taxpayer-funded consultant to prepare OAM nominations for NT agency labelled 'bizarre'

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Alan Joyce reportedly jets off with a substantial amount of cash and Qantas shares in his portfolio — but valid questions are being asked about whether he is entitled to all of it.

title.children: Qantas' board is under enormous pressure to scrap Alan Joyce's final payout. Could they actually do it?

image.altText: Catherine King stands at lecturn in front of airport signage

items.synopsis: Catherine King says the 2020 incident was one factor in her decision to reject Qatar's application to increase its flights to major Australian airports, but that no single issue swayed her one way or the other.

title.children: 'Absolute nonsense': Transport minister rejects claims Qatar flights would make big difference to ticket prices

image.altText: A black and white photo of a woman outdoors.

items.synopsis: For three months, this Swiss adventurer walked alone for 1,500 kilometres through parts of the Nullarbor, Great Victoria Desert and Gibson Desert. She says Australia is now "in her blood".

title.children: While trekking in remote Australia, Sarah didn't speak for six weeks. She says it is 'magical'

image.altText: Relaxed anonymous male teenager texting on mobile phone. His face is obscured by his hands and mobile in front of him.

items.synopsis: Recently emojis have landed some people in legal trouble in courts around the world. So what constitutes crossing the line?

title.children: Don't underestimate the legal implications of a thumbs-up emoji — it cost a Canadian man $90,000

image.altText: A woman in a yellow jacket, a woman in a navy jacket sit on a green bench seat while a man stands and shouts

items.synopsis: The heated discussion over why Qatar Airways' bid to increase flights to Australia was rejected has left the government juggling excess political baggage, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: 'C'mon, guys, you know people are watching': When all hell broke loose in Question Time, an independent stood up

image.altText: A globe centred on Australia showing rainfall anomaly patterns, mostly red to indicate dryness. A date indicates August 2023

title.children: An El Niño could be declared as early as next week: This is what it looks like when it forms

image.altText: A group of men wearing suits

items.synopsis: Police allege the 61-year-old concealed a serious indictable offence after the incident on Friday night, where two people were killed in Sydney's south-west.

title.children: Alleged driver's father charged with hindering investigation into fatal Heckenberg crash

image.altText: People stand on Primrose Hill, one man is shirtless, a woman has her hands on her head because of the heat.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: Earth experiences hottest Northern Hemisphere summer on record. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: a small shark out of water

items.synopsis: Three sailors attempting a round-the-world voyage have been rescued after their boat was attacked off the coast of Cairns and began to sink. It's suspected their craft was set upon by cookiecutter sharks.

title.children: How a 40-centimetre shark brought a catamaran's round-the-world voyage to a halt

image.altText: the front of a house and carport, with the ocean seen behind it

items.synopsis: The rise of short-term holiday rentals like Airbnb and Stayz have changed the way we travel, but they've also faced backlash over concerns they're driving rents up and exacerbating housing shortages in cities around the world.

title.children: Short-term rentals are often blamed for exacerbating the housing crisis. Now the regulation is catching up

image.altText: Jann Gilbert stands outside her fire damaged home in Mallacoota.

items.synopsis: Jann Gilbert knows what it's like to lose everything. The scars of her Black Summer experience are driving her fight for all new coal and gas project approvals to be paused.

title.children: Black Summer survivor abandoning home over fears for coming bushfire season issues desperate plea to Canberra

image.altText: An image of a woman with her face blurred walking out of a Gold Coast house with police

items.synopsis: Police allege three men have forked out nearly half a million dollars in what they describe as a "cruel" scam as they charge three people with fraud offences.

title.children: Dozens of victims could be linked to 'cruel' alleged romance scam as elderly men come forward

image.altText: A luxury cruise on the ocean ship beneath a clear sky.

items.synopsis: MS Caledonian Sky was arrested off Roebuck Bay late last month over a separate dispute. Now an international union alleges its crew was underpaid.

title.children: Luxury cruise ship detained off WA now at centre of wage theft allegations

items.synopsis: The drug Natalie Sinclair takes to keep her alive is among hundreds of medications that have been in short supply in Australia, but advocates fear stockholding laws for suppliers are having little impact on the ground.

title.children: More than 400 medicines are in ‘short supply’ in Australia. Advocates are calling for change

image.altText: UFC Middleweight title contender Sean Strickland at Sydney holding a microphone with NSW government logo beside him

items.synopsis: NSW sports minister says a whole sport can't be tarnished by "one or two people" after comments by controversial mixed martial arts fighter Sean Strickland ahead of the government-funded event.

title.children: NSW premier labels UFC fighter's sexist comments 'appalling' ahead of taxpayer-funded Sydney bout

image.altText: Composite photo of The Rolling Stones and Sydney Sweeney

items.synopsis: Fans haven't heard new music from the veteran rockers since 2005's A Bigger Bang.

title.children: Rolling Stones announce first album of new music in 18 years, bring Sydney Sweeney along for the ride

image.altText: Four Corners obtained footage showing the tear gassing of boys being held in isolation at the Don Dale Youth Detention Centre in Darwin, in August 201

items.synopsis: A Supreme Court justice orders the NT government to pay more than $200,000 each to four men who were tear gassed when still teenagers in the Darwin detention facility.

title.children: NT government ordered to pay nearly $1 million to former Don Dale inmates tear gassed in 2014

image.altText: A woman in a Voice Yes campaign T-shirt smiling and standing in a small park at the end of an outdoor mall.

items.synopsis: Yes campaign leaders say significant investment has been made into campaigning in the NT, despite votes from the territories having less sway in the referendum result.

title.children: The Yes campaign arrives in the NT. But how much of a difference will it make?

image.altText: An older man wearing a blue suit and tie and glasses sits in a room with a portrait of Australia's Parliament House behind him.

items.synopsis: Outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe will give his final public speech before handing over to Michele Bullock next week, while the ASX is trading down following poor US economic data prompted concerns interest rates will stay higher for longer. Follow live.

title.children: Philip Lowe to give final speech as RBA governor, ASIC sues PayPal Australia, ASX lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Anticipated strike action at Chevron's two major liquefied natural gas (LNG) projects in Western Australia hasn't gone ahead today, as unions and the company continue talks. Workers have been arguing for better pay and rostering and had threatened to start intermittent strike action from today. But talks continue, with workers at Gorgon, Australia's second largest LNG plant, and its Wheatstone operations voting to delay any work stoppages until 6am tomorrow. The ongoing dispute which made headlines a few of weeks ago, along with Woodside workers who were also threatening to walk off the job, sent the global price of LNG soaring. Australia is the world's biggest exporter of LNG, mostly supplying customers in Asia like China, Japan and South Korea. But of course these things ripple when we're talking global markets, so the threat of industrial action by workers in Western Australia impacts prices in Europe and elsewhere. The strike action could disrupt seven per cent of the global supply of LNG. Chevron has reportedly made provisions if workers do indeed down tools. Workers at Woodside's North West Shelf reached an agreement in late August, that guarantees total pay packets of more than $300,000 a year .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chevron workers are still working - for now

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello! Rachel Pupazzoni joining Kate on the blog as we're in for a busy day today. Before we hear from Philip Lowe for the last time, I thought I'd jump in with a bit more on another leadership change. No, not Qantas. That other, other leadership change that's made headlines recently. Remember last week when Andrew Forrest announced the chief executive of Fortescue Metals Group, Fiona Hick was out and Dino Otranto was now in the top job - on the same morning the top 10 ASX listed company was due to reveal it's full year results? On that day, they held their media and analyst briefing before they even published their annual results to the market (because there was a whole lot of name replacing going on in the documents) - it made for an engaging call that morning. By the way, Ms Hick is not the only exit - hardly a day has gone by since last Monday where another FMG high level executive or staffer hasn't left. But looking forward, Mr Otranto (title now CEO FMG Metals) and Mark Hutchison (CEO FMG Energy) have now held another briefing with analysts and our good friends at UBS have sent over a note from that discussion. The note from UBS analysts Lachlan Shaw, Levi Spry and Dim Ariyasinghe says: FMG explained that while former CEO Fiona Hick and CFO Christine Milne were highly regarded, the fit had not worked. A quick response was seen as in the best interests of shareholders and governance. Recent leadership changes reflected that the Board had decided the 'fit' of former CEO Fiona Hick and CFO Christine Milne was off, and saw fit from a governance perspective to move quickly to address. Management stability vs FMG's agile/ can-do decision making culture was taken into account. Until recently, FMG had allocated 10 per cent of its net profit after tax to be spent on Fortescue Future Industries projects. That has been removed, along with it the certainty of how much of the iron ore profits would be spent developing decarbonisation technologies. Mr Hutchison has been tasked with delivering five projects by the end of this year. I was chatting with a former FMG insider recently, who said even delivering one is a big ask. So I guess... watch this space. But back to the UBS, note. The analyst team's guidance is to sell FMG shares. We remain sell rated with $15.20/sh PT reflecting near term iron ore price caution on China steel production caps, and uncertainty on Energy project economics and execution risks. Fortescue shares are down slightly today - fetching about $20.33 .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: FMG briefs analysts on its plans, after that mass exodus triggered by CEO Fiona Hick last week

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ANZ has increased interest rates on all but one of its credit cards by 0.25 percentage points overnight. Customers with the ANZ Low Rate card will see a 1.25 percentage point increase, taking the interest rate to 13.74%. All credit cards with ANZ are also seeing a 0.75 percentage point increase to its cash advance and balance transfer rates — taking it from 21.24% to 21.99%. The annual fees on three ANZ cards will also increase from November 8 — its Rewards Platinum, Rewards, and Rewards Travel. Here's a breakdown of the interest rate changes on ANZ's credit cards, courtesy of RateCity: Low Rate: +1.25% to 13.74% (Annual fee: $0 for 1 year then $58) First: +0.25% to 20.49% (Annual fee: $0 for 1 year then $30) Platinum: +0.25% to 20.49% (Annual fee: $0 for 1 year then $87, or free if spend +$20K yearly) Rewards Platinum: +0.25% to 20.49% (Annual fee: $95 — increasing to $149 on November 8) Frequent Flyer Platinum: +0.25% to 20.49% (Annual fee: $425) Rewards Black: +0.25% to 20.49% (Annual fee: $375) Frequent Flyer Black: +0.25% to 20.49% (Annual fee: $425) Sally Tindall, RateCity.com.au's research director said the credit card fees were hiked by ANZ "in the dead of night". "For some ANZ card holders, this rate rise could pass them by if they’re not paying attention," she said. "In the last six months we’ve seen 10 lenders hike the rates on at least one of their credit cards, while seven lenders have increased annual fees. "This is yet another timely reminder to give your credit card a health check regardless of who the provider is."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ lifts interest rates on all of its credit cards

image.altText: A dam and rolling green hills.

items.synopsis: Researchers identify thousands of locations for potential micro-pumped-hydro energy storage across rural Australia, using pre-existing farm dams and rivers.

title.children: The classic farm dam could be capable of generating 30 kilowatt hours of power

image.altText: A woman stands at a table outside surrounded by buckets of pink and white Geraldton Wax flowers.

items.synopsis: Planting flowers in the middle of a drought doesn't seem like the obvious choice to diversify but this family has said goodbye to sheep and hello to hundreds of Geraldton wax plants.

title.children: In a horrible drought, Allie turned to flower growing and now her blooms sell out within the hour

image.altText: A submarine at the surface with morning sun on its right flank, the ocean stretches behind it

items.synopsis: As some Republicans raise concerns about the deal to supply American subs to Australia, a US Senate committee hears China's recent behaviour means "time is of the essence" in the trilateral AUKUS pact.

title.children: 'This is a critical moment': China's behaviour towards Australia makes AUKUS more urgent, US senator warns

image.altText: Garry Ringrose screams as he runs with the ball with three France players on the ground behind him

items.synopsis: Opta statistics say there are four clear favourites heading into the Rugby World Cup — but there's a major loophole that could mean the Wallabies have a deep run in the tournament, despite being ranked as major outsiders.

title.children: Who is going to win the Rugby World Cup? Opta says it's a four-horse race

image.altText: A Melbourne AFL captain smiles and high-fives teammates as they gather to celebrate a goal.

title.children: Why each team can — and can't — win the AFL flag in 2023

image.altText: Mark sits at his desk with a screen and laptop open in front on him talking to someone on his mobile phone.

title.children: Mark knows property managers have to make 'harsh' calls. Now he's on the other side

image.altText: An older man peers out his window. His chocolate brown cavoodle is on his lap and looks directly at the camera

title.children: 'People are going to die': David needed to go to hospital quickly and ended up ramped in emergency for hours

image.altText: A smiling, dark-haired man leans on a trailer full of oranges in a citrus orchard.

items.synopsis: There are fears that short-term contracts and low prices for Valencia oranges could force some growers out of the industry.

title.children: Orange industry in Australia shrinking to the point of collapse as short-term contracts, lower prices hit growers

image.altText: Forecast chart showing blue over Great Australian Bight and SA, polar air mass heading for country's south-east

items.synopsis: It was a sunny start to the week but from today a polar air mass will sweep over south-east Australia, causing temperatures to plummet by as much as 15 degrees Celsius in 24 hours.

title.children: Hail, snow and gales to replace spring heat in a battle of the seasons

image.altText: Donald Trump frowns in a mugshot, wearing a suit and red tie

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump's legal predicaments gain momentum ahead of 2024 electoral campaign, as he faces legal delays and a loss in his defamation case bid.

title.children: 'I look foward to testifying': Donald Trump says he will give evidence in classified documents case

image.altText: Aung San Suu Ky looks intensely into the camera at a conference.

items.synopsis: The son of Myanmar's detained former leader Aung San Suu Kyi says she is being refused urgent medical care despite her ill health.

title.children: Myanmar's ailing former leader Aung San Suu Kyi being denied medical care in prison, son says

image.altText: Four green cartoon mutant turtles burst through a set of doors, weapons drawn, including swords

items.synopsis: Writer Seth Rogen and director Jeff Rowe pay homage to their 90s childhoods in a fast and funny animated film packed with neurotic banter and pop culture references.

title.children: New Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles movie delivers 'a cinematic pizza-with-the lot'
